Definition: ID for the EoL database
The name of the organism, consisting of 2 terms in Latin: the first being the genus and the second being the species.
The taxonomic rank Order
The taxonomic rank Family
The taxonomic rank Genus
The taxonomic rank Species
Whether the animal is domesticated or the wild ancestor of a domesticated species or not. Species were defined as (1) domesticated or (2) wild.

Any measurable or observable behavioral characteristic related to a daily biological activity cycle. Species were defined as (1) nocturnal only, (2) nocturnal/crepuscular, cathemeral, crepuscular or diurnal/crepuscular and (3) diurnal only.
The amount of matter in the body of an organism.
The distance from point to point along the longest axis of the anterior/superior jointed appendages used for locomotion or grasping.
The distance from point to point along the longest axis of the body of an organism.
Age at which both eyes are fully open after birth.
Age at the first successful reproduction.

Basal metabolic rate (BMR) is the amount of energy expended daily by humans and other animals at rest. Rest is defined as existing in a neutrally temperate environment while in the post-absorptive state.
Mass of individual(s) from which the basal metabolic rate was taken.
Number of dietary categories eaten by an organism.
Age at which young permanently leave the parent, parental group, social group or any associated territories.
The length of time between when a fertilized egg implants in the wall of the uterus and the birth of offspring.
Number of habitat layers used by an organism.
Size of the area within which everyday activities of individuals or groups (of any type) are typically restricted.
Size of the area within which everyday activities of individuals or groups (of any type) are typically restricted.
The length of time between successive births of a female.
Single birth offspring quantity. The proportion or number of offspring produced from a single pregnancy (mammals) or ovulation (fish) or nesting (birds).
Number of litters per female per year.
The full period of time from birth to death of an organism.
The amount of matter in the body of an organism (newborn animal).
The distance from point to point along the longest axis of the body of an organism (newborn animal).
Number of animals in a population relative to space.
Number of individuals in a group that spends the majority of their time in a 24 hour cycle together.
The age at which an organism develops the ability to produce live offspring.
Number of individuals in a group that spends the majority of their time in a 24 hour cycle together where there is some indication that these individuals form a social cohesive unit.
The number of teats, protuberances on the mammary glands, breasts or udders of female mammals through which milk is excreted.

Degree of terrestriality of each species measured using any qualitative or quantitative time measure, for non-captive populations; adult or age unspecified individuals, male, female, or sex unspecified individuals; primary, secondary, or extrapolated sources; all measures of central tendency; in all localities. Species were defined as (1) fossorial and/or ground dwelling only and (2) above ground dwelling.

Position of an organism in a food web. May be described verbally with descriptors including primary producer, herbivore or carnivore. If described numerically, 1 indicates a primary producer, 2 a herbivore, and so on up the food web.
Age when primary nutritional dependency on the mother ends and independent foraging begins to make a major contribution to the offspringâ€™s energy requirements.
The amount of matter in the body of an organism (weanling).
The distance from point to point along the longest axis of the body of an organism (weanling).
What kind of food the animal eats. Species were defined as (1) frugivores, (2) granivores, (3) nectivores, (4) folivores, (5) lignivores or (6) multiple kinds.
The average amount of food the species eats in a day.
The degree to which the species tend to associate in social groups. Species were defined as (1) solitary or (2) in a group.
Whether there is a social hierarchy or not. They were defined as (1) social hierarchy or (2) no social hierarchy.

The number of mature males in a group of species. There could be (1) multiple males per social group, (2) one male per social group, (3) no males per social group/males live separately or (4) there is no social group/the species lives solitary.
The months needed for a male animal of the species to reach sexual maturity.
The months needed for a female animal of the species to reach sexual maturity.
The way the species group is structured in relation to sexual behaviour. The species' mating systems were defined as (1) monogamy, (2) polygyny and, (3) polygynandry.
The average amount of offspring per pregnancy.
Average number of days between two gestation periods.
Whether the species breeds (1) all year round or (2) seasonal.
The amount of kilograms the mature species weighs on average.
Whether the parents care for and rear the offspring or not. The species were defined as (1) parents care for offspring and (2) parents don't care for offspring.
Whether the offspring needs the help of the parents to survive, or they can do it by themselves. The species were defined as (1) precocial or (2) altricial.
Whether there is a sexual dimorphism in head ornaments. The species were defined as (1) there is sexual dimorphism in head ornaments and (2) there is no sexual dimorphism in head ornaments.
The average number of years the species lives.

Whether the species has natural predators in their natural habitat (not counting humans). They were defined as (1) having less than 3 natural predators (including 3), (2) having more than 3 natural predators or (3) not having natural predators.
Ability to move spontaneously and actively, using metabolic energy. The species were defined as (1) actively mobile, (2) facultatively mobile or (3) fast moving.
The average number of grams a mature species can carry. (For the purposes of this paper it is measured as 20% of the mature animal's body weight)
The amount of grams a mature species can pull. (Same as carry weight, 20% of the mature animal's body weight)
The average amount of kilometers per hour a mature species can run. Top speed is used instead when information about the average moving speed cannot be found.
The average amount of kilometers a mature species can walk/run per day. The size of the home range is used when information about the average travel distance cannot be found.
